Druga część trylogii "Nightmares from the Deep" stanowi osobną, prawie niezależną od pierwszej części grę z gatunku hidden object. Elementami wspólnymi jest główna bohaterka oraz nawiązania do "The Cursed Heart", które dodają produkcji smaczku, choć ich rozumienie nie jest konieczne dla cieszenia się rozgrywką. Można więc sięgnąć po "The Siren's Call" bez znajomości pierwszej części trylogii, ale gra trochę uroku na tym straci.

W tej części poprawiono właściwie wszystko, co było nie tak z jedynką. W kwestii grafiki zrezygnowano z kiepskiej jakości animacji wkładania talara (czy też w tym wypadku żetonu z rybą) do wgłębienia w skrzyni. Dodana została możliwość zablokowania ekwipunku w pozycji wysuniętej oraz podróżowania po świecie za pomocą klikania w odpowiednie miejsca na mapie. Sceny z ukrytymi przedmiotami zostały zróżnicowane nie tyle na mniejsze i większe co na "zwykłe" i takie, w których używamy jednego przedmiotu aby zyskać dostęp do innego, które moim zdaniem są znacznie ciekawsze. No i w końcu mamy do wyboru trzy poziomy trudności.

W kwestii mechaniki nie ma się już więc do czego przyczepić. Podobnie jest z oprawą audiowizualną - stoi ona na najwyższym poziomie. Obrazki nieruchome posiadają niezwykłą ilość szczegółów. Pozostałe elementy poruszają się płynnie i nie wytrącają ze świata gry, jak to czasem ma miejsce w grach tego typu. Muzyka wręcz perfekcyjnie utrzymuje klimat przez całą rozgrywkę, jednocześnie nigdy nie wychodząc na pierwszy plan. Naprawdę nie ma co tutaj dużo gadać - jeśli ktoś jeszcze nie grał to szczerze polecam, nie tylko fanom gatunku.

Le mieux est l'ennemi du bien. En voulant dynamiser son récit, Artifex Mundi a confondu vitesse et précipitation. Ce deuxième Nightmares from the Deep est un adolescent trop excité de nous montrer tout ce qu'il sait faire, démarre trop vite et finit trop vite. Dès le début de l'aventure, le musée de Sarah Black se fait (encore) attaquer. Une poignée de secondes plus loin, on se retrouve à Dieu sait combien de kilomètres, les deux pieds dans un nouveau pétrin ; une foule en colère veut brûler la maison de la poiscaille bipède en ciré jaune qui nous a emmené jusqu'ici. Et juste après, la [i]cutscene[/i] qui tache pour introduire le grand vilain et son gros monstre. Et la sirène. Et l'allusion à Davy Jones qui va bien. Tout ça en moins de cinq minutes. The Siren's Call, c'est cette nymphette qui vous attrape par l'avant-bras et vous plaque contre le mur des toilettes, les poumons gonflés d'oxygène pour mieux mettre en valeur son décolleté rembourré au PQ. C'est un jeu qui, trop pressé de nous en mettre plein la vue, oublie nous laisser le temps d'assimiler [i]punaise qu'est-ce qu'on fout là ?[/i].

Mis à part une entame et une fin expéditives, The Siren's Call est clairement l'un des meilleurs jeux du catalogue Artifex Mundi. Ses influences, plus exotiques qu'à l'habitude, nous changent de la piraterie classique du reste de la trilogie. Entre légendes mythologiques et Lovecraft mignon, The Siren's Call est un jeu à fort de son ambiance cohérente et facilement identifiable. On reconnaît les orfèvres polonais à la beauté des visuels, à la variété des puzzles, au rythme parfaitement dosé, à l'interface impeccable, à l'alternance entre les moments de point & click à l'ancienne et les séquences d'objets cachés toujours réussies, à la simplicité très [i]casual friendly[/i] de l'aventure. Un produit carré, comme souvent lorsqu'Artifex Mundi est au développement. On pourra regretter qu'il n'ait, comme on en a malheureusement l'habitude avec le genre du jeu d'objets cachés, que l'ambition d'être un scénario de plateau repas, un gentil téléfilm d'aventure familial.

Résolument féminins mais aussi féministes qu'un dossier spécial du [i]Figaro Madame[/i], les jeux Artifex Mundi oublient souvent d'être subtils. La fille Black étant absente de ce voyage, on est épargnés du regard maternel qui alourdit un peu plus encore les deux autres épisodes de la saga. Et en plus l'héroïne a l'intelligence de fermer sa bouche d'un bout à l'autre du script. Dans l'univers du HOG où les mémères s'extasient sur le moindre miaulement de chaton et refusent de toucher une toile d'araignée même pour sauver le monde, c'est un bundle de bonnes nouvelles.

S'il est le plus court et aussi peut-être le moins bon des trois, ce Nightmares from the Deep est fait avec tellement de sérieux, est rempli de tellement de bonnes intentions qu'il serait déraisonnable de ne pas le conseiller aux amateurs du jeu d'objets cachés : cette trilogie, même dans ce qu'elle réussit le moins, est l'une des meilleures oeuvres d'un éditeur qui ne les compte plus. Alors oui, on pourra toujours trouver matière à râler, refuser à l'envi d'ouvrir son oeil valide pour se concentrer sur le bandana qui nous obstrue la vue de l'autre. Plutôt que s'en faire des copains, entrer en guerre contre les termites qui nous bouffent la jambe de bois. Cet épisode, comme le précédent et comme le suivant, ne réinvente pas la voile. Il n'a pour lui aucun argument pour faire revenir vers lui ceux qui s'étaient lassés des HOG ; mais il a tout pour y garder les autres et continuer de les coucouner de ses câlins. Les jeux vidéo et les sirènes, c'est comme le verre à demi-plein ou à demi-vide. Tout dépend de quelle moitié on regarde.

Pour ceux qui se poseraient la question : non, il n'est pas capital de faire les épisodes dans l'ordre.

Nightmares from the Deep 2: The Siren`s Call to kontynuacja ciepło przyjętej, stworzonej przez polskie studio przygodówki z elementami logicznymi i hidden object, osadzonej w pirackich klimatach. W grze po raz kolejny wcielamy się w pracownicę muzeum Sarę Black, która wplątuje się w nową, mroczną, morską przygodę. Podążając śladem tajemniczego artefaktu, bohaterka trafia do odciętego od zewnętrznego świata, tejemniczego i ponurego rybackiego miasteczka, sprawiającego wrażenie jakby czas przestał w nim płynąć kilkaset lat temu i zamieszkanego przez przypominających ryby ludzi. Szybko okazuje się, że nad wyspą ciąży klątwa, a nasza bohaterka jest jedyną osobą zdolną do jej zdjęcia.

Pod względem rozgrywki The Siren`s Call nie różni się od poprzedniczki. Opiera się ona na eksplorowaniu kolejnych lokacji, odszukiwaniu ukrytych przedmiotów oraz rozwiązywaniu logicznych łamigłówek. Praktycznie w każdym momencie rozgrywki gracz może skorzystać z podpowiedzi. Dodatkowo może po pewnym czasie pominąć łamigłówki, a zamiast sekwencji hidden object może rozgrywać partie mahjonga. Ukończenie obu wątków fabularnych gry to zajęcie na ponad cztery godziny, a odnalezienie wszystkich znajdziek i zdobycie wszystkich osiągnięć to kolejne kilka godzin zabawy.

Nightmares from the Deep 2 trzyma poziom oryginału. Gra całkiem dobrze oddaje mroczny klimat Karaibów. Składa się na to ciekawa fabuła i w głównym stopniu piękna oprawa wizualna. Lokacje wyglądają znakomicie, widać, że twórcy zadbali o każdy szczegół. Bardzo dobrze prezentują się też przerywniki filmowe. W przeciwieństwie do pierwszej części Nightmares from the Deep, tutaj wyrenderowano je w wysokiej rozdzielczości, dzięki czemu jest czym oko nacieszyć. Niczego też nie można zarzucić rozgrywce. Elementy przygodowe są dobrze zaprojektowane i zachowują logiczny ciąg przyczynowo skutkowy. Kilka nowości można dostrzec w sekwencjach hidden object. Oprócz tych klasycznych, polegających na odszukiwaniu wskazanych obiektów na danej scenie, są też takie, w których szukamy kolejnych przedmiotów i używamy ich do zdobycia następnych. Przykładowo musimy znaleźć kluczyk do szafki, z której wyciągniemy szyfr do sejfu, w którym znajduje się poszukiwana przez nas rzecz. Przyjemne urozmaicenie. Łamigłówki logiczne rozwiązuje się przyjemnie. Nie są bardzo trudne, ale do banalnych też nie należą.

Czy The Siren`s Call powiela błędy swego pierwowzoru? Nie. A przynajmniej nie w tym samym stopniu. W pierwszych Koszmarach z Głębin bardzo denerwowały mnie błędy ortograficzne. Tutaj niestety też zdarzają pewne anomalie językowe. I choć jest ich tu mniej i nie rażą tak bardzo w oczy, to ciągle jestem zdania, że w naszej rodzimej produkcji nie powinno ich być w ogóle. Niby mi to nie przeszkadzało i łamigłówki rozwiązywało mi się dobrze, ale przypuszczam, iż nowe zagadki przyjąłbym jeszcze lepiej.

Podsumowując, Nightmares from the Deep 2: The Siren`s Call to kolejna porcja tego samego. I to nie w złym znaczeniu. Jest to solidna produkcja typu Hidden Object Puzzle Adventure. Oferuje ciekawą fabułę, przyjemną rozgrywkę i piękną oprawę wizualną i z pewnością spodoba się wszystkim fanom gatunku. Warto się z tym tytułem zapoznać, nawet jak nie grało się w pierwszą część serii, bo nie ma tu do niej aż tak wielu nawiązań.

Игра повествует нам о смотрительнице музея на пиратскую тему, чьё ночное дежурство привело к встрече с загадочным курьером принесшим неизвестный груз, и это стало началом освобождения нашей героиней, города людей-рыб от проклятия, наложенного на них из-за жадности их мэра заключившего сделку с Дэйви Джонсом. Сюжет ИМХО чуть более глубок и интересен чем в первой части, хотя и там он был неплох. После прохождение основной кампании откроется бонусная, где наша героиня сможет узнать чуть больше о личности Дэйви Джонса. И заодно, если в первой части события происходили на корабле и на острове, здесь они происходят в рыбацком городке.

2) Геймплей: игровой процесс тот же, что и в первой части, и почти такой же как и во многих других играх жанра "поиска скрытых предметов". Головоломки стали несколько сложнее чем в первой части, по количеству их примерно столько же сколько разгребания бардаков в поисках нужной штуковины. Поиск скрытого предмета можно заменить партией в маджонг, поэтому любителям "идеальных игр", нужно пройти игру 2 раза, один только с поиском, другой только с маджонгом. Кроме того добавился необязательный квест на сбор нужных предметов, за это дают ачивки - это осьминоги, их хорошо видно, морские коньки, нужно активировать нужную вещь в области тогда они появятся, и птички, они сливаются с пространством, плюс исчезают на время, их найти сложнее всего. Есть бонусный раздел со сценами поиска, концепт-артом, видео, обоями на рабочий стол, и музыкой. Встроенное прохождение которое было в первой части, здесь отсутствует.

3) Графика и звуки: в игре неплохая английская озвучка, хорошая, но не шедевральная музыка. Графика довольно красивая для игр такого жанра, плюс стало больше видеовставок чем в первой части, из-за этого эта часть смотрится визуально интереснее.

Как итог: любителям казулок, игр на пиратскую тему, "поиска скрытых предметов", категорически рекомендую.
8 сирен из 10.

Here, we have the second instalment of [i]Nightmares from the Deep series[/i]: [i]The Siren's Call[/i]. Artifex Mundi keeps upping the game and brings another succeeding HOG in. Compared to the first game, [i]The Siren's Call[/i] carries a faster pace in story with just as good puzzles and HOG scenes. In this game, we'll have less undead, more... fishmen?

The museum curator Sarah Black's adventures in the Caribbean continues. After her remarkable encounter with Captain Remington, Sarah is safely back and prepares for a new exhibition while trying to promote a "fiction" novel about her last encounter with Captain Remington. It is the middle of the night when a strange courier visits the museum to deliver a package. With the content of the package revealed, Sarah suddenly becomes a target again and a central figure in an old curse that slowly transforms the inhabitants of Kingsmouth to fishmen. You are to become a part of the resistance against a corrupt mayor, free a siren and challenge the curse of Davy Jones himself yet again.

Catchy, huh? Yeah, I know. Some might think that [i]Nightmares from the Deep[/i] series are basically a retelling of [i]Pirates of the Caribbean[/i] movies. Even I thought so when I finished the first game. This one, obviously gathers anecdotes from [i]Dead Man's Chest[/i] and [i]On Stranger Tides[/i], but still manages to harbor the Caribbean lore into something curious and genuine. The bonus chapter at the end of the game even presents some foreshadowing about the last instalment, namely the origin of infamous Davy Jones himself. I really expect something a bit different than the movie version Davy Jones. Here's hoping!

I'll just skip praising the quality of artwork in Artifex Mundi games and define with two words: plain gorgeous. It is no big news that Artifex Mundi redefined the HOG genre, especially with the quality of artworks. This one is no different. Aside lovely background visuals with strong nautical themes, character animations are really good in this one compared to the first instalment. Characters have distinct facial remarks and body language. Cinematics seem to improve quite a bit too.

The gameplay? As a HOG, it is more than decent with presenting different type of HOG scenes, one or two FROG scenes and some puzzle dynamics even in HOG scenes themselves. Puzzles are mostly ordinary with lovely artworks this time. You'd go through the most challenging one within 3-4 minutes. If you are bored with HOG gameplay, you may give Mahjong alternative gameplay a try anytime you wish. To grab all achievements, you'll be needing at least two playthroughs though: one for HOG achievements, one for Mahjong achievements. The map is interactive with "available action" indicators so backtracking is not an issue. We are already familiar with collecting coins and poking a - this time fish-dwarf to tell us the background story. I'm getting used to these guys. Sure they are creepy as fuck, but hey! They are company.

[i]Nightmares from the Deep 2: The Siren's Call[/i] is a good addition to the series, building up the concept further and establishing a bridge between the first and the last game, and a neat HOG by itself. Pick it during a sale and enjoy!

И во все это сразу погружаешься: бульк! Как в воду с головой. Тут довольно вольное обращение с мифами. Не древнегреческую музу Калиопу героиня будет пытаться вызволять из кареты-акваримума. А скорее персонажа из фильмов про пиратов Карибского моря. Того и гляди, Джек-Воробей из какого-нибудь трюма выскочит. 
Еще есть мини-игра, из которой можно получить знания о существовании такого блюда как крабовый пирог. 
Надо отметить, что головоломки довольно сложные, и их много. Особенно это касается типа заданий «найдите и используйте».  Нужно найти в сцене определенные предметы по силуэтам, а потом догадаться, как их использовать между собой, чтобы найти новые предметы или что-то открыть.  В общем, новичкам, пожалуй, не стоит начинать знакомство с жанром квестов с этой игры. А вот ценителей наоборот она может изрядно порадовать. К плюсам также можно отнести красивую графику. Конечно, я имею в виду не внешность мэра, а интерьеры, окружение. А еще сюда непонятно как затесался синий прихвостень из игры Overlord, которого именуют «карликовым дьяволенком». 
К минусам можно отнести неудачный – скорее для разработчиков – список достижений. Им стоило, как в игре Abyss: The Wraiths of Eden, сделать достижения за прохождение на уровне эксперт, за мини-игру. Но здесь большая часть достижений сюжетная, т.е. пропустить никак нельзя. Зато есть достижения, для которых требуется найти определенные фигурки, разбросанные где угодно по игре. Осьминоги обычно серые и камуфлируются с окружением. Попугаи имеют свойство появляться не сразу, надо подождать секунд 10. Тогда на какой-нибудь жердочке иногда появляется попугай. Чтобы найти морских коньков, нужно выполнить действия. Например, позвонить в колокольчик, повращать колесо в типографии. В любом случае по игре есть гайд в Стим, где описано, как их всех найти.  Еще, на мой взгляд, слишком много внутриигровых документов. Многие персонажи любят вести дневники, где рассказывают обо всех своих секретных замыслах. А потом удивляются, почему восстание против мэра провалилось? Как он узнал об их планах?
В общем, я рекомендую эту игру, особенно если вам нравятся фильмы про пиратов Карибского моря.  Однако что до меня, то она не совсем отвечает моим вкусам.

The second game in a present series of three.  It is stand alone, and can be played out of order.  However, as with all series games, each game despite its own individuality does build on the previous story and there are previous story references. 

Story: Museum Director Sarah Black, who has gained a reputation by breaking a Davy Jones' curse, is brought an 'artifact' by a mysterious man.  The 'artifact', however, belongs to a pirate captain Murray who has made a deal with Davy Jones.  Captain Murray, now mayor of the town Kingsmouth, wants it back.  The artifact powered by the 'magic' of his captive mermaid controls the ship destroying kraken.  The mysterious man, suffering under the curse brought on the captain's deal (along with the entire town Kingsmouth) wants back his humanity and to free the captive mermaid.  He enlists Sarah's aide to free the mermaid and to break Davy Jones' curse.  

This game plays in a very tight linear fashion based on a chase theme.  Once finished with an area the player moves on giving chase.  There is back tracking in this game but not enough to be annoying, or even seemingly out of place.  The flow of the story and gameplay is smooth, each obstacle the goal to overcome as the player gives chase.  As far as any back tracking that does occur, the no penalty fast travel map makes it easy and convenient.  Of course puzzles, hidden object scenes, needed items or things to do can also be deduced from the map.  Your intrepid companion steers the player along the game path as well as through the story, and needs to be talked to prompt the game.  However talking with your companion comes off as a natural thing to do and never seems forced.  In many ways the story is about your companion and your character Sarah is the by-stander, helper and observer.  

There is a wide variety of puzzles and hidden object scenes, and what I have come to think of as Artifex Mundi's trademark (at least in this series): Mahjong.  Depending on personal gameplay style there is enough variety of game choice to not be boring.  No single puzzle or hidden object scene is overly difficult but also not so easy as to be considered too simple.  The hidden object scenes occur frequently enough for the game to be hold the designation 'Hidden Object' game and not fall into the 'point and click' category.

There are also three sets of 'ghost/shape shifting/extra' objects to look for: octopi, parrots, and seahorses.  The parrots fade in and out at approximately 10 second intervals.  The seahorses are 'ghosts' that appear when certain objects are touched.  The octopi are simply hidden within the background.  Of the three, the parrots are the hardest to find and there are lots of them.  If any thing in this game could truly be called challenging I would say finding all of these extras without consulting a guide would be.

The bonus chapter gives background to both Captain Murray and Davy Jones, as well as a teaser for the next game in the series.

One last thing, I thought the chest guardian in this game was very apropos.  Though I did miss the little animation of him taking the coin each time (as it happened in the first game), but I can understand why the action would only be shown once and not repeated.  (I guess I do not mind repetitive things.) 

Enjoyed the game and enjoy the series.

I'm not the sort to prejudice games over things like their being hidden object puzzlers; and the Artifex Mundi games are by far the best examples of the genre. Nonetheless A.M. has followed the method of if it isn't broke don't fix it, meaning they reuse their puzzles with cosmetic variations from one game to another. This has the unfortunate result that if you've played one of their games you've played them all.

That's O.K. if you think of the games as more visual novels with bonus puzzle content. Granted the writing isn't amazing; but it isn't bad either. I know I've yet to play an A.M. game I could make myself stop playing before the end. That's, on average, over 3 hours in one sitting. And, most of their games include a bonus chapter that extends gameplay another hour.

They do manage to do this without unnecessarily padding game length that overstays its welcome. I know that doesn't sound like much in an industry with triple AAA titles that boast hundred of hours of gameplay. But, for cheap casual games this is an achievement.

My recommendation, because of the "if you've played one you've played them all" problem, is pare your selections down to their better games. That would be Enigmatis 2 (but not the mediocre Enigmatis: the Ghosts of Maple Creek) as a top pick, Grim Legends 1 & 2 if you liked that, and the Nightmares from the Deep trilogy if you just can't get enough of these games.

14220223.review:
Nightmares from the Deep: The Cursed Heart represented [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/mrninjasquirrel/recommended/259740?snr=1_5_9__402]something of a low point[/url] in Artifex Mundi's library for me, so approaching The Siren's Call I didn't have the highest of expectations, or really any to speak of. Maybe it was the lack of enthusiasm on my part or the benefit of having a few other Artifex Mundi games pop up between its two pirate themed adventures. but Nightmares of the Deep managed to avoid the vast majority of the problems which brought down its predecessor and could easily sit as one of the developer's most polished works.

In a lot of ways, Artifex Mundi has "fixed" Nightmares of the Deep by basically retconning the entire first game. It follows a nearly identical premise, features similar puzzles, and has effectively the same structure as The Cursed Heart. In some ways this makes it feel somewhat redundant, as if you've played the prior game there's a constant feeling of deja vu following you around as Artifex Mundi mostly tries to pretend that game doesn't exist. But they've also done so much to improve the originally underwhelming experience that I still found myself enjoying their signature brand of casual adventure game HOGs (hidden object games) and appreciating the ways they'd found to streamline and subtly enhance a familiar formula. It also means that if you never played The Cursed Heart you're under no obligation to before The Siren's Call, as for all intents and purposes this is a second start for the series, and a markedly better one at that.

Siren Call's most immediate upgrade is its visuals, especially that of character faces and animations. Gone are the unnerving lip spasms, clunky walks, and convenient tricks to hide a lack of animation, replaced with actual facial movements and a significant increase in the amount and quality of animation in every area of the game. It might still be fairly tame compared to games with budgets in the multi-millions, but it goes a long way to making Siren's Call stand out among its peers as almost certainly the prettiest HOG I've ever played.

Other fixes are less overt but no less desirable, such as fast travel carried over from previous Artfiex Mundi games which cuts out all the tedious backtracking that was at its worst in Cursed Heart, helping especially in making the end game fetch quest something I actually enjoyed. Contextual puzzle solving has a much larger focus now, with logical solutions that make you feel more like an improvising scavenger than someone that just happened to stumble into a pile of junk with everything you need. They're a lot of small alterations that might not be immediately apparent, but make it hard to imagine going back to the way games of the genre have been for so long.

The one place Siren's Call failed just as much as its predecessor is its narrative, which once again borrows heavily from Disney's Pirates of the Caribbean. I wouldn't say I expect to find Pulitzer worthy writing in this style of game, but Artifex Mundi's prowess at delightfully cheesy plots remains nowhere to be found in Nightmares from the Deep. Plot holes abound, motives feel contrived and character reactions even more incomprehensible, and in general Siren's Call is trying so hard to be serious that it just comes across as dry and frankly pretty boring.

Compared to The Cursed Heart's list of annoyances though, that's a not insignificant step up in quality, and leaves the inevitable third game in a position to finally bring the series up to the standards Artifex Mundi has set themselves with other games. I'm still not entirely sure why Nightmares of the Deep seems to be the flagship title in their eyes, but if future games can keep in line with The Siren's Call I wouldn't be all that bothered to have a few more of them.

解谜上，本作沿袭了前作的系统，个人感觉谜题设置更合理了一些（少跑了很多冤枉路），而且为了避免过多寻物游戏引起的头晕眼花进而砸鼠标键盘（这也是我前作最诟病的地方），制作组特意增加了许多新的寻物方式，这个好评。还一个不错的地方是隐藏物品成就，三个成就分别对应着三种找隐藏物品的方式，一周目不看攻略的话确实很难找齐。不过为了成就强行二周目的老毛病依旧存在，说实话作为一个剧情解谜双一般的游戏为了成就二周目有点傻……看在二周目也就2h 上下的份上就算了。

总体来说还是很不错的快餐解谜游戏，有卡有成就，成就很好刷。而且简中好评，适合各位在玩各种大作之余轻松一下。当然，依旧不建议全价买。

This was a solid hidden object game, and I enjoyed it more than the first "Nightmares from the Deep" title.

Gameplay involves a wide variety of puzzles and challenges such as:
1. Traditional hidden object screens (clearly denoted by sparkles on the easier difficulties), and FROG (fragmented object) puzzles.  These HOGs and FROGs were well-constructed with clean art and a satisfying level of difficulty. 
2. Bonus game-wide "I-spy" style challenges including octopi (concealed within level backgrounds), seahorses (exposed by certain hand icon actions), and owls (disappearing, reappearing background images).  The seahorses and octopi were fairly simple to find once you knew what you were looking for, but waiting around for the owls to appear was a bit tedious at times.  Additionally, unlike AM's more recent titles with this kind of bonus content, there is no on-screen indicator to let you know if you missed one of these objects on a particular screen.
3. An assortment of brainteaser mini-games like tile-swapping, rotating discs, jigsaws, matching, and spot-the-difference puzzles.  There were a handful of new surprises and unique challenges; however, many of the puzzles were what I have come to see as trademark mini-games for this studio ("arrange the books," "plug in the four cables," "place all the gears," "rotate the discs," etc). Artifex Mundi returns to the Nightmares from the Deep setting (piratey horror), but not to the well... okay, maybe there's a little well water.  But it comes from a nicer well.  A shinier well!  It even has a new bucket!  The result is a solid adventure game that is leaps and bounds better than its predecessor, taking many lessons from Mundi's other games since the first Nightmares.

You'll notice I called this an adventure game and not a hidden-object game.  There is just so much they've expanded this (and other Artifex Munid games) into that to categorize it strictly as a hidden-object game is to do so in error.  First off, like in the first Nightmares, if you don't even like HOGs, you can bypass all of them by electing to play Shanghai instead (still erroneously called Mahjong here, but whatever... I'm over it....).  More importantly, while there isn't an avatar for you to move around the screen and dialogue windows with people who ask you for weird objects for no reason (adventure game basics, people), the game also provides variations on classic slider puzzles, pictograms, cryptograms, and even its own take on Mastermind.  Sure, HOGs are still a big draw of the game, but go on and click through the screenshots and tell me how many actual HOG scenes you see - not many.  Keep in mind, however, that those are only the screenshots - there are plenty in the game so you won't be disappointed if that's what you came for.

The end result of mashing all of these gametypes into one game would have you thinking that it doesn't work, but AM has finely crafted Nightmares 2 with its own kind of puzzle language and nothing seems out of place.  More importantly, especially when compared to the first game, Nightmares 2's hardest difficulty is actually a decent challenge.  It won't really stump veterans, but no longer is everything sparkly and saying "click me" unless you want it to.  Here you may need to backtrack far just to find the one HOG you waltzed past or perhaps one that activated retroactively just to find what you need to continue.  Still, with a handy fast-travel map, none of it is really all that tasking for players.

And what of the extra little bits?  Throughout the game, there are hidden objects for you to find that aren't in the hidden object scenes.  These come in the shape of octopusses (octopi?), seahorses, and silver effing parrots.  While the first two are easy enough to find, the parrots are the WORST.  If you are obsessive about these things, like I am, then the parrots are going to irritate you.  Why?  Because they disappear.  That's right.  They phase in and out of reality for NO DAMNED REASON.  And if, like me, you refuse to cheat, it can be a daunting task to figure out exactly which one you're missing because damn if you remember clicking every single one.  But let me tell you something - I got 'em all.  SUCK ON THAT!

Where was I?

Is the game perfect?  Nah.  No game is.  Parrots are a good reason to ding the game, but more importantly, I found that some of the backtracking actually was a bit of a problem, especially on the expert mode.  While it's not a big deal to go and find the next HOG you need to work on, the issue arises when one that you've already solved becomes activated again.  Half the time I would just walk on past because I figured I did that one already.  On a second playthrough, this was compounded by the fact that I knew I would have to eventually go to that spot to get what I needed, but each HOG activates on a specific set of events being completed so it could very well be that you can't find anything in that one space, go solve a puzzle elsewhere, and suddenly that space is activated just moments after you were there.  It can be confusing, but again, this really only an issue with the hardest difficulty.  But hey, I can't be all glowing positive, right?

So let's pick on the story, then.  Very simply, we see the return of the curator from the first game being approached by a man in a raincoat who has some sort of special artifact for her.  In the opening scenes, we return to the museum in the first Nightmares in a nice nod to the prequel, but after a few introductory puzzles, kiss it goodbye and enter the realm of Kingsmouth (like Innsmouth), filled with a population of fish people.  Not that piratey, but still aquatic.  See, some dude named Mayor Murray (really), has kidnapped Caliope, the Siren, and by extension now controls the Kraken, threatening any foreign ship entering Kingsmouth's waters.  It is your job to set Calliope free and save the world or something.  I honestly didn't pay much attention this time around because it's pretty standard fare.

So, the short version - if you're looking for a continuation of the story because you were a big fan of the first game, you might be disappointed because it's only loosely related.  If, on the other hand, you are looking for a solid adventure game filled with some fun puzzles you can hash out while sipping on your favorite beverage, you'll enjoy this.  Artifex Mundi has really nailed down their craft, and I couldn't be happier for it.

12324322.review: It's an Artifex Mundi point and click / hidden object / puzzle game! I have no shame in finding these to be a guilty pleasure, because they're a nice change of pace from more demanding games. This one maintains the devs' usual decent standards, with generally good presentation throughout (with some weird exceptions, as though a different artist was roped in at knife-point to fill in certain gaps). The formula does wear a little thin towards the end, and there's a certain sense of going through the motions that's not evident in the first two thirds of the game. You know the drill: explore locations, pick up items, do hidden object scenes to find necessary objects to solve puzzles (in this game, they really like "swap the pieces around so they form the right picture / match the background"), and listen in horror to some stilted voice acting. It starts well, with much drama and a cutscene that they probably blew half the game's budget on (this probably explains the marionette-like animation later in the game), and then settles into a comfortable formula. Towards the end it actually starts to get, dare I say it, quite exciting! I nearly spilled my tea at one point. The dramatic music helps, and threads begin to wrap up towards the big showdown, but it never really challenges you and feels a bit anticlimactic. If you get "stuck" it nearly always means there's a new hidden object scene that's opened up somewhere on the map, and you have to wander around until you find it. Frustratingly, there are occasions where apparently useful objects can be seen in the background art, but which are non-interactive (in reality the location of the object you need is elsewhere). It's sloppy. Removing useful objects (like a hammer) and then requiring you to find another one later in the game is also annoying. However, like its terrible voice acting (one actor is wildly inconsistent, seemingly forgetting the character he's playing mid-sentence on several occasions), it comes with the territory.
